awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Electrostatic Normal Force Modulation for Haptic Touch Screens
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will advance the development of electrostatic surface haptics as a means of providing tactile feedback for touchscreens.  In electrostatic surface haptics, a user's finger(s) are selectively pulled down to a glass surface by an electrostatic potential, just as a capacitor's plates are attracted to one another.  The enhanced normal force leads to an enhanced frictional force when the fingers are moved across the surface.  By modulating the electrostatic force in response to finger position and time, a great variety of compelling haptic percepts can be created.  In previous work, low voltage techniques, thin hard high dielectric coatings, a way of avoiding the necessity of grounding the user, patterns of transparent conductor that allow different fingers to experience different sensations, and some of the software controls, were developed.  In Phase II, methods of finger position sensing that are fully compatible with haptic actuation will be developed.  The new methods also offer the possibility of discriminating multi-touch fingers according to same or opposite hand, or the fingers of a second person on the same touchscreen.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project stems from enriched communication with touchscreen devices. Already touchscreens are of immense commercial importance.  The worldwide market for touchscreen modules grew three-fold from 2009 to 2011 with smartphones, tablet computers, and automotive display applications leading the charge.  Consumers have been attracted to the versatility of touchscreens as input devices, yet the absence of haptic feedback has limited accessibility for low-vision populations, exacerbated safety concerns in applications such as driving, and prohibited the aesthetics of touch from being fully developed.  Surface haptics technology has the potential to address all of these weaknesses.  It can be used to make user interface elements operable by touch alone, to create new interaction metaphors, and to enhance the overall user experience.  By addressing known and latent needs in the marketplace, surface haptics will foster new industrial growth.

por.por_cntn:
Billions of devices have touchscreens, which provide consumers input versatility yet offer little when it comes to touch feedback ("haptics").  Haptic feedback to the user via the sense of touch has long been promised but has been delivered only as vibrations of the device, which are generally experienced as unsatisfying.  In contrast, Surface Haptics modulates the friction felt by each finger as it slides on a glass touchscreen surface.  Friction modulation under software control can produce perceptions of the edges of keys and buttons, textures, contours, inertia, and other forces.  The objective of the SBIR research was to prove the viability and commercial value of Surface Haptics using an electrostatic method of friction modulation coupled with finger position sensing for commercial applications.

 

The Phase I research focused on overcoming several hurdles to commercialization associated with electrostatics.  In electrostatic Surface Haptics, a user's finger(s) are selectively pulled down to a glass surface by an electrostatic potential, just as a capacitor's plates are attracted to one another.  The enhanced normal force leads to an enhanced frictional force when the fingers are moved across the surface.  By modulating the electrostatic force in response to finger position and time, a great variety of compelling haptic percepts can be created.  The team developed low voltage techniques, a novel thin film construction for the sensor, a way of avoiding the necessity of grounding the user, and the software controls to enable developers to create multi-sensory experiences.  These goals were accomplished using known manufacturing processes and readily available materials while maintaining the current architecture of touch display devices.  The overall transformative impact of a touchscreen that enables a device to communicate via the sensory dimension of touch will forever change how users interact with touchscreen devices.  Surface Haptic technology can improve functionality of user interface controls by allowing users to navigate via the sense of touch.  Automotive applications in particular see great value in this new functional capability because Surface Haptics allows driver to operative touch displays in cars while keeping his/her eyes on the road.  Additionally, Surface Haptics can improve interface accessibility for users with vision or hearing disabilities.  Finally, the commercial potential was validated through joint development agreement with a major consumer electronics manufacturer.

 

During the Phase II and IIb portions of the grant, the primary objectives were to incorporate multi-touch finger position sensing with Surface Haptics on the same glass, develop the sensor to allow different fingers to experience different sensations, and complete a software development kit (SDK) to provide software developers the tools to create multi-sensory applications that include the dimension of touch.  These objectives were met with the invention of a novel method to simultaneously sense finger position and administer Surface Haptics.  Upon completion of the technology and development of the Development Kit, the technology was unveiled to the world at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in January 2017.  Our booth generated a great deal of excitement from the consumer electronic industry and press alike, including winning numerous awards from technology magazines and market analytics firms.  More importantly, the show generated an enormous amount of awareness for our technology translating into a wave of inquiries to utilize our technology in a variety of products and markets.  Today the company is partnering with leading companies in the automotive and technology markets to incorporate surface haptics in their product offerings.
